description.en: Northern Thailand’s cultural hub, known for its old city, night markets, temples, and nearby mountains.
description.nl: Het culturele hart van Noord-Thailand, bekend om de oude stad, markten, tempels en bergen.

enhanced_description: Northern Thailand’s cultural hub, known for its old city, night markets, temples, and nearby mountains.

hidden_gems.name: Local Market Near Doi Suthep
hidden_gems.story: There's a small local market that most tourists miss, tucked away near Doi Suthep. Locals do their daily shopping here.
hidden_gems.how_to_find: Ask any local for the 'talad sod' (fresh market)
hidden_gems.best_time: Early morning (6-9 AM) for the freshest items

hidden_gems.name: Sunset Viewpoint
hidden_gems.story: I discovered this quiet spot perfect for watching the sunset over Chiang Mai. No crowds, just peaceful views.
hidden_gems.how_to_find: Usually located on higher ground or by water

authentic_experiences.name: Join a Local Temple Morning Routine
authentic_experiences.story: Wake up early and join the locals giving alms to monks. It's a peaceful way to start the day and connect with Thai Buddhist culture.
authentic_experiences.cultural_significance: Merit-making is central to Thai Buddhist practice
authentic_experiences.how_to_participate: Arrive at 6 AM, buy food offerings from local vendors

authentic_experiences.name: Learn to Cook at a Local Home
authentic_experiences.story: Skip the tourist cooking classes and learn from a Thai family. The dishes taste completely different when made with generations of knowledge.
authentic_experiences.cultural_significance: Food is family heritage in Thailand
authentic_experiences.how_to_participate: Ask guesthouse owners for family connections

foodie_adventures.name: Street-side Pad Thai
foodie_adventures.story: The best pad thai I've ever had came from a cart that only operates after 6 PM. The vendor has been perfecting her recipe for 20 years.
ordering_tips: Ask for 'mai pet' if you don't want spicy

foodie_adventures.name: Morning Market Som Tam
foodie_adventures.story: The papaya salad at the local morning market is incredibly fresh - they pound it right in front of you with ingredients picked that morning.

local_insights: Locals eat dinner much earlier than in Western countries - around 6-7 PM
Pointing with your index finger is considered rude - use an open hand instead
Remove shoes before entering homes and some shops
The king is deeply revered - always show respect when his image or anthem appears
Tipping is not expected but small amounts are appreciated for good service
Learn the word 'krub' (for men) or 'ka' (for women) - it makes any sentence more polite

seasonal_secrets.why: Most comfortable weather for walking and outdoor activities
insider_tips: Book accommodations early during peak season
Rainy season (July-October) has fewer crowds and lower prices
Hot season (March-June) is perfect for indoor activities and temples

money_saving_tricks: Eat where locals eat - much cheaper and often better
Use public transport instead of taxis
Buy fruit from markets instead of tourist areas
Stay in local guesthouses rather than international hotels
hidden_costs: Tourist temples often charge entrance fees

travel_tips: Best time to visit Chiang Mai is during the cool season (November-February)
Learn basic Thai phrases for better local interactions
Always carry cash as many places don't accept cards
Respect local customs and dress modestly at temples
Try local street food but choose busy stalls for freshness

best_time_to_visit.reasons: Ideal weather conditions for sightseeing and outdoor activities

budget_info.notes: Budget includes accommodation, food, transportation, and activities
